summary:
The pound is a unit of mass used in British and U.S. measurement systems. The most common type is the international avoirdupois pound, which is equal to 0.45359237 kilograms. It is divided into 16 ounces. The symbol for this pound is "lb."

The pound's origin traces back to the Roman "libra," and its name comes from "libra pondo," meaning "weight measured in libra." Today, the term "pound" usually refers to the avoirdupois pound. Historically, other types of pounds existed but are now replaced by the metric system.
title: Pound (mass)
